document.title: Convolution semigroups, canonical processes, and Brownian motion

section.title: 1Convolution semigroups, projective families, and canonical processes

para.p:
For
∈ x E

Math.text: nu ^ x * f = (integral _ E)@(f * d * nu * delta _ x)
nu ^ x * f
absent = (integral _ E)@(f * d * nu * delta _ x)
absent = (integral _ (E * E))@((f compose A) * d * nu * delta _ x)
absent = (integral _ (E * E))@((f compose A) * d * nu * delta _ x)
absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(f * (x _ 1 + x _ 2) * differential-d@(delta _ x) * x _ 2) * differential-d@(nu) * x _ 1)
absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(f * (x _ 1 + x _ 2) * differential-d@(delta _ x) * x _ 2) * differential-d@(nu) * x _ 1)
absent = (integral _ E)@(f * (x _ 1 + x) * differential-d@(nu) * x _ 1)
absent = (integral _ E)@(f * (x _ 1 + x) * differential-d@(nu) * x _ 1)

X

para.p:
Forgetting the stochastic process
X
, a family of probability measures
P J
on
E J
, for
∈ J K
, is called a projective family when () is true. The Kolmogorov extension theorem tells us that if
(
P J
)
∈ J K
is a projective family, then there is a unique probability measure
P I
on
E I
such that for any
∈ J K
,

Math.text: pi _ (list@(I, J)) _ * * P _ I = P _ J

para.p:
Then for
= Ω
E I

E I

P I

para.p:

Math.text: X _ J = pi _ (list@(I, J))

For

E n

Math.text: (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@(1 _ B * vector@(x _ 1, ldots, x _ (n - 1), x _ n) * differential-d@((nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) ^ (x _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * differential-d@((nu _ t _ 1) ^ (x _ 0)) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ 0))) = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@(1 _ B * vector@(x _ 1, ldots, x _ (n - 1), x _ n + x _ (n - 1)) * differential-d@(nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * differential-d@((nu _ t _ 1) ^ (x _ 0)) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ 0))) = cdots = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@((1 _ B compose sigma _ n) * differential-d@(nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 1) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ 0)))

P J

For

Math.text: (integral _ (E ^ n))@(f * differential-d@(P _ J)) = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@((f compose sigma _ n) * differential-d@(nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 1) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ 0)))

para.p:
Let
( Ω , F , P ,
(
X t
)
∈ t I
)
be a stochastic process with state space
E
.
X
is said to have stationary increments if there is a family
(
ν t
)
∈ t I
of probability measures on
E
such that for all
∈
s , t
I
with
≤ s t
,

Math.text: P _ * * (X _ t - X _ s) = nu _ (t - s)

para.p:
In particular, for
= s t
this implies that
=
⁢
P *
( 0 )
ν 0
, hence
=
ν 0
δ 0
.

A stochastic process is said to have independent increments if for any
∈ J K
, with elements
0 =
t 0
<
t 1
< ⋯ <
t n
, the random variables

Math.text: list@(X _ t _ 0, X _ t _ 1 - X _ t _ 0, ldots, X _ t _ n - X _ t _ (n - 1))

para.p: are independent.

We now prove that the canonical process associated with the projective family of probability measures induced by a convolution semigroup and any initial distribution has stationary and independent increments. 2 2 footnote 2 Heinz Bauer, Probability Theory, p. 321, Theorem 37.2.

Let
(
ν t
)
∈ t I
be a convolution semigroup, let
(
P J
)
∈ J K
be the family of measures induced by this convolution semigroup, let
∈ μ
⁢ P
( E )
, and let
( Ω , F ,
P μ
,
(
X t
)
∈ t I
)
,
= Ω
E I
and
= F
E I
, be the associated canonical process.
X
has stationary increments,

Math.text: formulae@((X _ t - X _ s) _ * * P ^ mu = nu _ (t - s), s less= t)

para.p: and has independent increments.

(q compose Y) ^ (- 1) * B
absent = conditional-set@(omega element-of Omega, (q compose Y) * omega element-of B)
absent = conditional-set@(omega element-of Omega, X _ t * omega - X _ s * omega element-of B)
absent = conditional-set@(omega element-of Omega, X _ t * omega - X _ s * omega element-of B)
absent = (X _ t - X _ s) ^ (- 1) * B
absent = (X _ t - X _ s) ^ (- 1) * B

para.p: and thus

Math.text: (q compose Y) _ * * P ^ mu = (X _ t - X _ s) _ * * P ^ mu

para.p: Now, according to (),

Math.text: Y _ * * P ^ mu = pi _ (list@(I, set@(s, t))) _ * * P ^ mu = P _ (set@(s, t))

Therefore, using that

(X _ t - X _ s) _ * * P ^ mu * B
absent = (q compose Y) _ * * P ^ mu * B
absent = Y _ * * P ^ mu * q ^ (- 1) * B
absent = Y _ * * P ^ mu * q ^ (- 1) * B
absent = P _ (set@(s, t)) _ * * q ^ (- 1) * B
absent = P _ (set@(s, t)) _ * * q ^ (- 1) * B

absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ (q ^ (- 1) * B) * open-interval@(x _ 1, x _ 2) * differential-d@((nu _ (t - s)) ^ (x _ 1)) * x _ 2 * differential-d@((nu _ s) ^ x) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x)))

absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ (q ^ (- 1) * B) * open-interval@(x _ 1, x _ 2) * differential-d@((nu _ (t - s)) ^ (x _ 1)) * x _ 2 * differential-d@((nu _ s) ^ x) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x)))

absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ (x _ 1 + B) * x _ 2 * differential-d@((nu _ (t - s)) ^ (x _ 1)) * x _ 2 * differential-d@((nu _ s) ^ x) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x)))

absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ (x _ 1 + B) * x _ 2 * differential-d@((nu _ (t - s)) ^ (x _ 1)) * x _ 2 * differential-d@((nu _ s) ^ x) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x)))
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B * (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(differential-d@((nu _ s) ^ x) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x))
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B * (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(differential-d@((nu _ s) ^ x) * x _ 1 * differential-d@(mu) * x))
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B * (integral _ E)@((nu _ s) ^ x * E * differential-d@(mu) * x)
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B * (integral _ E)@((nu _ s) ^ x * E * differential-d@(mu) * x)
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B * (integral _ E)@(differential-d@(mu) * x)
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B * (integral _ E)@(differential-d@(mu) * x)
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B
absent = nu _ (t - s) * B

para.p: which shows that

Math.text: (X _ t - X _ s) _ * * P ^ mu = nu _ (t - s)

para.p:
and thus that
X
has stationary increments.

Math.text: formulae@(Y _ 0 = X _ t _ 0 - X _ t _ (- 1), formulae@(Y _ 1 = list@(X _ t _ 1 - X _ t _ 0, ldots), Y _ n = X _ t _ n - X _ t _ (n - 1)))

para.p:
For the random variables
Y 0
, … ,
Y n
to be independent means for their joint distribution to be equal to the product of the distributions of each, i.e. to prove that
X
has independent increments, writing

Math.text: Z = Y _ 0 tensor-product cdots tensor-product Y _ n = tau _ n compose (X _ t _ 0 tensor-product cdots tensor-product X _ t _ n) = tau _ n compose X _ J = tau _ n compose pi _ (list@(I, J))

para.p:
with
:
τ n
→
E
+ n 1
E n
defined by

Math.text: tau _ n * vector@(x _ 0, x _ 1, ldots, x _ n) = vector@(x _ 0, x _ 1 - x _ 0, ldots, x _ n - x _ (n - 1))

para.p: we have to prove that

Math.text: Z _ * * P ^ mu = ((product _ (j = 0)) ^ n)@(Y _ j _ * * P ^ mu)

para.p:
To prove this, it suffices (because the collection of cylinder sets generates the product
σ
-algebra) to prove that for any
∈
A 0
, … ,
A n
E
and for
A =
∏
= j 0
n
A j
∈
E
+ n 1
,

Math.text: Z _ * * P ^ mu * A = ((product _ (j = 0)) ^ n)@(Y _ j _ * * P ^ mu) * A

para.p: i.e. that

Math.text: Z _ * * P ^ mu * A = ((product _ (j = 0)) ^ n)@(Y _ j _ * * P ^ mu * A _ j)

para.p: We now prove this. Using the change of variables theorem and (),

Math.text: Z _ * * P ^ mu * A = (integral _ (E ^ (n + 1)))@(1 _ A * d * Z _ * * P ^ mu)
Z _ * * P ^ mu * A
absent = (integral _ (E ^ (n + 1)))@(1 _ A * d * Z _ * * P ^ mu)
absent = (integral _ Omega)@((1 _ A compose Z) * differential-d@(P ^ mu))
absent = (integral _ Omega)@((1 _ A compose Z) * differential-d@(P ^ mu))
absent = (integral _ Omega)@((1 _ A compose tau _ n compose (X _ t _ 0 tensor-product cdots tensor-product X _ t _ n)) * differential-d@(P ^ mu))
absent = (integral _ Omega)@((1 _ A compose tau _ n compose (X _ t _ 0 tensor-product cdots tensor-product X _ t _ n)) * differential-d@(P ^ mu))
absent = (integral _ (E ^ J))@((1 _ A compose tau _ n) * d * X _ J _ * * P ^ mu)
absent = (integral _ (E ^ J))@((1 _ A compose tau _ n) * d * X _ J _ * * P ^ mu)
absent = (integral _ (E ^ J))@((1 _ A compose tau _ n) * differential-d@(P _ J))
absent = (integral _ (E ^ J))@((1 _ A compose tau _ n) * differential-d@(P _ J))

Then applying () with

Math.text: (integral _ (E ^ J))@((1 _ A compose tau _ n) * differential-d@(P _ J)) = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@((1 _ A compose tau _ n compose sigma _ (n + 1)) * differential-d@(nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1)))) = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@(1 _ A * vector@(x _ (- 1) + x _ 0, x _ 1, ldots, x _ n) * differential-d@(nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1)))) = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(cdots * (integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * (x _ (- 1) + x _ 0) * 1 _ A _ 1 * x _ 1 * cdots * 1 _ A _ n * x _ n * d@(nu _ (t _ n - t _ (n - 1))) * x _ n * cdots * d@(nu _ t _ 0) * x _ 0 * d@(mu) * x _ (- 1)))) = ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(nu _ (t _ j - t _ (j - 1)) * A _ j * (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * (x _ (- 1) + x _ 0) * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1))))

,

Math.text: (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * (x _ (- 1) + x _ 0) * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1))) = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * (x _ (- 1) + x _ 0) * differential-d@(delta _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1)))
(integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * (x _ (- 1) + x _ 0) * differential-d@(nu _ t _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1)))
absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * (x _ (- 1) + x _ 0) * differential-d@(delta _ 0) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1)))
absent = (integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x _ (- 1) * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1))
absent = (integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x _ (- 1) * differential-d@(mu) * x _ (- 1))
absent = mu * A _ 0
absent = mu * A _ 0

para.p: and therefore

Math.text: Z _ * * P ^ mu * A = (mu * A _ 0) cdot ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(nu _ (t _ j - t _ (j - 1)) * A _ j)

para.p:
But we have already proved that (), which tells us that for each
j
,
and thus

para.p:
But
=
⁢
Y 0
*
P μ
⁢
X 0
*
P μ
and from () we have

Math.text: X _ 0 _ * * P ^ mu * A _ 0 = (integral _ E)@(X _ 0 _ * * P ^ (delta _ x) * A _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x) = (integral _ E)@(pi _ 0 _ * * P ^ (delta _ x) * A _ 0 * differential-d@(mu) * x)

para.p: and, from (),

Math.text: pi _ 0 _ * * P ^ (delta _ x) * A _ 0 = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x _ 0 * differential-d@((nu _ 0) ^ y) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(delta _ x) * y))
pi _ 0 _ * * P ^ (delta _ x) * A _ 0
absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x _ 0 * differential-d@((nu _ 0) ^ y) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(delta _ x) * y))
absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x _ 0 * differential-d@(delta _ y) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(delta _ x) * y))
absent = (integral _ E)@((integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x _ 0 * differential-d@(delta _ y) * x _ 0 * differential-d@(delta _ x) * y))
absent = (integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * y * differential-d@(delta _ x) * y)
absent = (integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * y * differential-d@(delta _ x) * y)
absent = 1 _ A _ 0 * x
absent = 1 _ A _ 0 * x

para.p: thus

Math.text: X _ 0 _ * * P ^ mu * A _ 0 = (integral _ E)@(1 _ A _ 0 * x * differential-d@(mu) * x) = mu * A _ 0

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: Z _ * * P ^ mu * A = (X _ 0 _ * * P ^ mu * A _ 0) cdot ((product _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(Y _ j _ * * P ^ mu * A _ j) = ((product _ (j = 0)) ^ n)@(Y _ j _ * * P ^ mu * A _ j)

para.p:
which completes the proof that
X
has independent increments. ∎

In any case, () is sufficient for (iii) to be true. Moreover, (iii) means that

in the topology of convergence in probability; this is proved using Egorov’s theorem. Thus, a
d

0
is a Lévy process; we do not merely assert that the Brownian motion formed in Theorem is a Lévy process. There is much that can be said generally about Lévy processes, and thus the fact that any
d
-dimensional Brownian motion with starting point
0
is a Lévy process lets us work in a more general setting in which some results may be more naturally proved: if we work merely with a Lévy process we know less about the process and thus have less open moves.
